title.narrative: FRA Uganda SP Right to Food 2019-2020

description.narrative: FRA will amplify voices of the consortium CSOs and small-scale food producers in relation to secure seeds and land rights at national level for effective engagements on policy issues by both government and private sector. FRA will be a national convenerresponsible for identifying and creating platforms for Right to Food Partners at all levels and mobilizing support of the consortium in all fora that advance small scale and women food producers# rights to seeds and land. FRA will also strengthen the program media engagements and presence, collaborations and linkages with key government entities, private sector players to voice key concerns related to seeds and land rights. Examples of polices that FRA will focus on include: For Uganda not to sign ARIPO#s Arusha protocol on PlantVariety Protection Act and ensuring that the Draft National Plant Genetic Resources Policy for Food and Agriculture passed and implemented

participating-org.narrative: Food Rights Alliance is a coalition constituted in 1999 to bring together Civil Society Organizations working in the field of sustainable agriculture and food security in Uganda. At the formation, it focused on the launch of the WTO#s new round of talks, which took place in Seattle, concerning international agreements, globalization processes and genetic modification. In 2000, other important issues were tabled for discussion, including the Government of Uganda#s Plan for Modernization of Agriculture (PMA). Currently, the Alliance is driven by a vision of #A world free from hunger and malnutrition# and pursuing a mission of #Promoting the realizationof the right to food in Uganda through Advocacy, Knowledge Management and Capacity Development#. FRA isimplementing a five year Strategic plan with the goal of building a strong alliance that effectively engages her membership and stakeholders to influence policy, systems and practices that affect the realization of the right to adequate food. All her programs target women as first recipientssince they have the primary role of feeding the family/s 2. ACHIEVEMENTS The Alliance has made numerous achievements since its inception. Among such accomplishments include; a committed membership of over 50 organizations that have kept it alive over the past years; Influenced direction of government negotiations e.g. WTO and EPA negotiations to pay special focus on agriculture and farmers# livelihoods; mobilized communities and the public for pre and post budgetengagements with special focus on agriculture; it has been part and partial of the CAADP processes at national and regional levels - it#s part of the national steering group of Non State Actors on CAADP, the development of the Development Strategy and Investment Plan for Agriculture, the development of the National Development Plan and now the negotiations with government regarding the implementation of the Uganda Nutrition Action Plan (UNAP), a process being coordinated by the Office of the Prime minister. The alliance has designed and implemented several campaigns focused onspecific issues in the agricultural sector aiming at creating an enabling environment for farmers especially women to produce food sustainably and meet the food and nutrition demands for the people in Uganda and in the region. These among others include, that national campaign on ending land grabbing launched in 2012, the campaign for an inclusive Agricultural Extension Service for all farmers launched in 2013 and engaged government on various policy processes including the formulation of the National Seed Policy, the Plant Variety Protection Act 2014, the Plant Health and Protection Act 2015. All these achievements have benefitted men, women, children and all Ugandan enormously. 3. INSTITUTIONAL PURPOSE Mission: The Mission is to promote the realization of the right to food inUganda through Advocacy, Knowledge Management and Capacity Development. Institutional objectives - To influence policy and practiceat different levels towards the realization of the right to food. - To develop knowledge based systems for effective engagement of members in the realization of the right to food. - To strengthen the capacity of the alliance and its membership to effectively deliveronits mandate. Field(s) of activity: - Advocacy - Knowledge management - Capacity building A range of social actors benefit fromFRA#s work differently, campaigns have assisted to bring duty bearers and rights holder together to discuss issues that affect their livelihoods. In most cases the beneficiaries are women as a group with the primary responsibility of feeding the family. The government has benefitted from NSA#s group contribution to policy reviews, now policies especially agriculture relatedeither reflect the interests of the local farmers or the policy markers now have a common platform of Non state actors they can consult on matters affecting local farmers. 4. STRATEGIC POSITIONING FRA through its membership has a country wide representation thus easily reaching all concerned parties. Through forged partnerships exhibited through the creation of Non state Actors# platforms that implemented campaigns focused on specific issues in the agricultural sector such as; aiming at creating anenabling environment for farmers to produce food sustainably and meet the food and nutrition demands for the people in Uganda and in the region. Through similar platforms, FRA has led engaged the government at local and national levels, at the national levelit led campaigns on; ending land grabbing launchedin 2012, an inclusive Agricultural Extension Service for all farmers launched in 2013 and engaged government on various policy processes including the formulation of the National Seed Policy, the Plant Variety Protection Act 2014, the Plant Health and Protection Act 2015. These campaigns have put FRA in a leading role that enables it interact and work together with government, civil society as well as business community in her campaigns.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood

description.narrative: Improved policies: # of cases where Oxfam/partners influenced governments or global actors in adopting/implementating policies on (i) Sustainable Food production and consumption, (ii) Land Rights and (iii) Climate Change with a gender senstive lens.
